description.narrative: The AACJ consortium in South Africa will develop broad alliances on climate justice by uniting movements that represent impacted communities with organizations and campaigns that advance climate justice and challenge extractive industries’ impact on the environment. The consortium will develop the capacity of local organizations to increase their autonomy and ability to self-organize as a transversal grass-roots movement, including by facilitating the development of common agendas and a unified voice between CSOs and climate justice activists, particularly women, youth, indigenous people and local communities (Pathway 1 and 2). The AACJ consortium will work with local/ impacted communities to i) challenge unjust policies and practices that are currentlyin place, such as governmentsupport for fossil fuel energy and land grabs; and ii) support and promote policy reform for climate justice, including mainstreaming of environmental issues throughout government and public policy (Pathway 5). Activities include training indigenous people, women, youth and local communities to increase climate-related knowledge and participation in policy procedures. The programme will also support local communities and environmental defenders to articulate and defend theirenvironmental and land rights, through legal empowerment and support (Pathway 3). Finally, the programme will document best practices on climate-related traditional knowledge and customary practices, for example through participatory action research and provide spaces for sharing, co-creation and promotion/ advocacy (Pathway 4).

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam South Africa is an independent Oxfam affiliate who manages and implements the programme of Oxfam in South Africa. Its programme prioritises vulnerable communities and creating lasting change in, and for all the people in South Africa. Oxfam South Africa works in partnership with organisations who seek to create meaningful and sustainable change that benefits vulnerable groups in South Africa through the attainment, protection and preservation of human rights and social justice. The country program will continue to focus its work through ‘active citizenship and accountability’ and ‘gender justice’ lenses.

comment.narrative:
Engagements on the rights of communities to Free Prior and Informed Coast on the Wild Coast where OZA supported research by renown journalist Lucas Ledwaba. The transcripts of interviews articulate the challenges faced by coastal communities when their rights are disregarded https://www.mukurukurumedia.co.za/2021/12/07/amadiba-take-on-shell-in-bid-to-preserve-coastal-land/ and
https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2021-12-05-hell-no-shell-people-around-south-african-coast-gather-to-fight-wild-coast-survey/

comment.narrative: Preliminary meetings held with officials and political heads at Amajuba District Municipality near Newcastle KwaZulu Natal. Internally OZA is exploring a Memorandum of Understanding with the South African Local Government Association (SALGA) to engage with municipalities on the need to have Climate Adaptation Plans in place and strengthening their capacity to raise climate funds and further structure community levels.

Preliminary meetings held with officials and political heads at Amajuba District Municipality near Newcastle KwaZulu Natal. Internally OZA is exploring a Memorandum of Understanding with the South African Local Government Association (SALGA) to engage with municipalities on the need to have Climate Adaptation Plans in place and strengthening their capacity to raise climate funds and further structure community levels.
